PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer diet
( ) Pioneer schools
( ) Pioneer churches
( ) Pioneer recreation and social life
( ) Pioneer farming experiences
( ) Folklore in Saskatchewan
( ) Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: J.H.M. ROBERTSON, G.A.K.B.U.R.N.
2. Your address: RIVERCREST, SASK.
3. Date: May 4, 1955
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Near London, Ont.
5. What was your father's name and occupation? George Cockburn, Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): April, 1902
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible:
   Born in Ont. Came west at age of 10
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc):
   10 years old
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   Came with my parents who homesteaded at Rouleau, Sask. My father having taken land 1 mile west of that town in 1900
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?):
    My father had shipped cattle to Calgary before 1900, and in 1900 shipped work forces to Regina, and heard about Rouleau County and took up the homestead there.
1. Your full name: John Robertson
2. Your address: Briercrest, SASK.
3. Date: May 1st, 1935
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country): Yessyton, Ont.
5. What was your father's name and occupation? George Cockburn Farmer
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year): April, 1902
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan:
   Esting and wherever possible.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need
   to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a
   small child", "I was in my teens", etc).
   10 years old
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   Came with my parents who homesteaded at Rouleau, Sask., 5 miles from the railway station in 1900
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?
    Rail road or government information)?
My father had shipped cattle to Calgary before 1900, and in 1900 shipped work horses to Regina, and heard about Rouleau County and took up the home stead there.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

I can well remember as a boy, the neighbors that two were going to Wilderness, and I looked forward to seeing Indians and having one of these Ponies.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

My father beta Car load Settlers effects and I came with my mother on train, took nearly a week.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Train

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.).

I remember the old frame Station in Moose Jaw getting in about 6 PM and waiting till after midnight for a train down the Soo Line. The floor was covered with Immigrants who had laid their blankets on the floor and went to bed for the night.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

In a shack 1 mile west Rouleau, Mr. and my Parents had one end of this and 4 horses lived in the other end.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

In 1906 my father sold his land at Rouleau Sask although at that time it was Rouleau, Assiniboe, North-West Territory, the Province of Sask not being formed till 1905, and we came to live at Brinecrest.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

Coming as a boy to the County, I did not worry much about a living although I remember we lived very plain at the age of 17 I started farming in the Brinecrest district and have been here ever since.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Canada?

I can't remember as a boy, the neighbors thought I was going to be a farmer, and I worked toward becoming an Indian and helping out of the Ponies.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with party (family, friends or other group)?

My father took a car and steamship and I came with my mother on train back nearly a week.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Train

---

14. What incidents of the journey? (People you met on the way? Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

I remember the old frame station in Montana feeling in about 6 PM and waiting till after midnight for a train down the Soo Line. The floor was covered with emigrants who had lost their blankets on the floor and were to bed for the night.

---

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

In a shack 1 mile west of Boulaw. Not and my parents lived near end of this and 4 houses lived in the town, and

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

---

17. In 1906 my father sold his land at Rockham South of that time it was Rockham. But in 1906 the land was not being farmed west of the town. The province of Saskatchewan was still 1905, and we came to live at Princeton.

18. How old you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? Roy, after you came?

Coming here a boy to the country, I didn't worry much about living, also I remember we lived very plain at the age of 17 I started farming in the Bracken district and have been here ever since.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

For several years I wrote to a girl I had went to school with in Ontario.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Nora Butten, July 10, 1912, at Moose Jaw.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

And the town of Briercrest came to be a town.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

I have a sister, Mrs. Jessie McPherson who came west the same time I did. She resides here at Briercrest. Also a brother Geo. Cockburn, he settled at Borden, Sask., in 1903. Then Saskatchewan.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Can well remember going to school and seeing the Indians on their trips to Regina for supplies following the old Wood Mountain trail, which passed close to Rouleau. This trail was well beaten and the Mounted Police had their post at Wood Mountain. I understand the Indians and Breeds got the job of hauling these supplies. I visited them camps different times.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

In 1905 my father took us all to Regina in a covered buckboard as some called them following the Wood Mountain trail for 25 miles. As a boy I soon got my pony and that was the way I done my visiting and it wasn't too often.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

Note: July 10, 1912, at Moose Jaw.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.

I have a sister, Mrs. Jessie Macdonald who came west by rail via Prince Albert, then by horseback via Prince Albert to Regina.

Geo. Cockburn, residing at Brandon, South, in 1903.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to recount?

Can well remember going to school and seeing the Indians on their way to Regina for supplies following the old Wood Mountain trail, which passed close to our place. This trail was used by the Mounted Police and the North West Mounted Police. I understand the Indians and the North West Mounted Police supplied the Indians with food during difficult times.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far?

In 1903 my father took two acres to Regina in December on Breck Road as some cattle then following the Wood Mountain trail for 25 miles, as a boy I would get my pony and that was the way I done my visiting and it wasn't too often.
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   1910

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?
   I got my first car 1917, make Ford

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Princeton, Sask., 16 miles. Brinecast at that time was called P.O.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   The Railroad came thru this district in 1911 and the town of Brinecast came to be a town

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   Sometimes a week. Sometimes near a month

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   About 1913

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   Around about 1906 my mother sent orders to Eaton's. Mostly clothing as I remember

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   1917

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   Got into the country and never made enough to get out, but still think there is no better place
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   - 1910

26. If you owned a car before 1910, did you buy it at that time?
   - Yes

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   - Winnipeg, Manitoba, 16 miles

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   - The railroad came through this district in 1911 and the town of Brinecast came to be a town

29. How often did you shop in the early days?
   - About twice a week, sometimes twice a month

30. When did people in your district first start going to town regularly?
   - About 1913

31. When did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?
   - Around about 1906 my parents started ordering

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   - 1917

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time, who fitted you with the idea of staying permanently?
   - Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

Got in to the country and never spread enough to get out, but I think there is no better place
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

A large number of homesteaders moved for the deed for their land and sold it and disappeared, as only about half of them were farmers anyway.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920's? Did many return?

Not many in this district moved away in the 30's

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My Brother Geo. Cockburn, who settled at Border. Such was Liberal member for Redberg near Saskatoon being elected I believe about 1918 and serving 16 yrs. after that was Sheriff at Battleford for 10 yrs. and at present retired and lives in Battleford.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible. (Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

My father was instrumental in getting the first School in this district, known as the Palmer S.D. around about 1908 or 9. I served nearly 20 years on the Brinecrest School Board about 10 yrs. as chairman.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Capt. Jacques who had the first P.O., named it Brinecrest he drew the mail from Drinkwater, Sask on the 900 Line C.P.R. Palmer School was named after a Negro boy that name who had homesteaded here.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1927? What reasons did they have for moving?

A large number of homes were vacated by people who moved away due to the Great Depression.

Only about half of them were farmers anyway.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

Not many in this district moved away in the 1930s.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

My brother Geo. Cockburn, late Secretary of Brady, was a liberal member for Paddery. His education being excellent & belief about 1915 and serving 1899, often.

He was elected as Paddery for 1910, and at present is still.

And living in Brady now.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "firsts" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible.

(Such as owning the first automobile, combining, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

My father was instrumental in getting the first school in this district. Known as the Palmer School around 1908 or 9. It served nearly 20 years or the

Palmer School closed about 10 yrs ago.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.) Try to give (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in name since the first name was given, date, and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

Capt. Gaynors who lived at first Po. named it Brinegar.

He chose the name from Brinegar In Sack on the Geo. Sack C.P.R.

Palmer School was named after a Negro boy that name

We had homes located here
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?

........ (indicate your preference, if any) ...................

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

We have 6 children namely, Woodrow, Chartered Accountant with Southern Pipe Line, Sask., G. Ledge, married June 13th, Gertrude married June 1st, Barbara, married, lives at Bear Plain, Sask., Donald, married farming on the home farm, Keith married, Service Manager for Phillips T.V. and Radio, Vancouver, B.C., also 12 Grand Children.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

I have seen many important changes from Owen to MacLeod and Combines, also when railway was built this district can remember when from Hill Hills south of us to Regina was Prairie Grass, a matter of 60 miles of flat country, today is all broke for many years and the best Wheat Country in the Province.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

My brother Geo. Cockburn, 1871-1971, St. North Battleford, Sask.
